body.Action Required: A Mitigation and contingency plan shall be identified and closely tracked by the risk owner. Risk may be accepted with proper justification.

Not acceptable; Risk must be treated by the risk owner or approved by Management/CISO. Critical risks shall be monitored on a periodic basis and these risks should be highlighted in project review meetings

body.Description: Risk is under observation post-treatment or awaiting changes.
Risk has been identified and assessed, but not yet treated or accepted.
Controls are being implemented or risk mitigation is in progress.
Residual risk is within acceptable limits and formally accepted.
Risk has been treated and no longer poses a threat (or is no longer relevant).
Risk is known but treatment is postponed (e.g., due to budget or priorities).

body.Types of Impact: Software bugs, hardware defects, poor performance, failure to meet specifications.
Delayed deliveries, unmet expectations, high complaint volumes, loss of clients.
Missed deadlines, inefficient development or QA processes, unstable DevOps.
Rework costs, SLA penalties, increased support costs, revenue loss.
Non-conformities, certification risk, unmet quality clauses in contracts.
Negative brand perception, poor reviews, reduced customer trust and retention.
Exposure of source code, client data leaks (e.g., PII, PHI), unauthorized access to repositories or cloud environments, vendor/supplier data leakage.
Tampering of source code or build pipelines, corrupted data during transmission or storage, compromised audit logs, altered client deliverables.
Downtime of applications/services (due to attacks or failures), unavailability of CI/CD tools, disrupted deployments or client access to products.
Violations of HIPAA, GDPR, ISO 27001, SOC 2 requirements; breach notification obligations; fines or contract terminations.
Loss of client trust (especially regulated industries), bad press, loss of certifications, damaged standing in vendor listings or RFP processes.
Penalties, legal fees, client compensation, breach response and recovery costs, SLA violation penalties, revenue loss from terminated contracts.
Delay in SDLC activities, backlog in sprints or releases, additional work to recover or secure systems, disruption in DevOps/Agile workflows.

Disruption to network or infrastructure availability, increased response time to incidents or tickets, delayed patching or vulnerability remediation, loss of access, unauthorized changes to system configurations.

Breach of employee personal data (PII), loss of access to HRMS or payroll systems, delay in onboarding/offboarding processes, increased workload due to manual fallback methods, employee dissatisfaction due to transparency or communication gaps.

Disruption to CI/CD pipelines, delay in code commits, builds, or releases, integrity loss in version control systems, unauthorized access to repositories (GitHub, Bitbucket), delay in hotfixes or feature delivery, compromised test environments impacting QA.

Loss of access to campaign tools (e.g., CRM, email automation), leak of customer contact lists or campaign strategies, inability to track or report campaign KPIs, delay in launching product announcements, brand damage, reputation damage.
